snippet: The state said that at least 11 people had died and that about 30,000 had been rescued after a storm system dumped more than 20 inches of rain in two days....
abstract: Louisiana is grappling with aftermath of flooding along Mississippi River that has obliterated homes and communities, killing at least 11 people and prompting rescue of 30,000; scientists note increase in heavy rainfall and say disaster fits into unprecedented pattern of flooding exacerbated by climate change and development.

byline.original: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON and ALAN BLINDER
byline.contributor: Campbell Robertson reported from Denham Springs, and Alan Blinder from Atlanta. John Schwartz contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: The state said that at least 11 people had died and that about 30,000 had been rescued after a storm system dumped more than 20 inches of rain in two days.

headline.main: As Louisiana Floodwaters Recede, the Scope of Disaster Comes Into View
headline.print_headline: Grim View Emerges as Louisiana Flood Recedes
